County Dublin(lang-gaContae Bhaile Átha Cliathhttp://www.logainm.ie/pdf/10.09.23_BRAINSE.pdforContae tha Cliath) is aCounties of IrelandcountyinRepublic of IrelandIreland. It is sometimes officially referred to as theDublin Regionand is in theProvinces of IrelandprovinceofLeinster. It is named after the city ofDublin, which is the regional capital and thecapital cityof Ireland. County Dublin was one of the first parts of Ireland to beshiredby KingJohn of Englandfollowing theNorman invasion of Ireland.

Prior to 1994 County Dublin was also an administrative unit covering the whole county outside ofDublin City Council. In 1994 Dublin County Council was abolished and replaced with three separate administrative county councils:Dn LaoghaireRathdown,FingalandSouth Dublin.
The population of the county was 1,270,603 according to the census of 2011.Census of Population 2011: Preliminary Results, Central Statistics Office. Retrieved 30 October 2011
article.heading: Local government and politics
article.paragraph: There are fourLocal governmentlocal authoritieswhose remit collectively encompasses the geographic area of the county and city of Dublin. These areDublin City Council,South Dublin County Council,Dn Laoghaire-Rathdown County CouncilandFingal County Council.

There is also Dublin Regional Authority which has authority over the while county but this body has few powers. It consists of 30 representatives who meet once per month.Irish Region Office - Regions of Ireland: Dublin RegionThese representatives are nominated from the four administrative councils of the region. Like each Regional Authority, it is assisted in its duties by an Operational Committee and EU Operational Committee.

Prior to theAct of the Oireachtasenactmentof theLocal Government (Dublin) Act 1993, the county was a unified whole even though it was administered by twoLocal authoritylocal authorities-Dublin County CouncilandDublin Corporation. Since the enactment of theLocal Government Act 2001in particular, the geographic area of the county has been divided between three entities at the level of "county" and a further entity at the level of "city". They rank equally as first levellocal administrative unitsof theNUTS 3 statistical regions of the Republic of IrelandNUTS 3Dublin Region forEurostatpurposes. There are 34NUTS of the Republic of Ireland#Local administrative unitsLAU 1entities in the Republic of Ireland. EachLocal government in the Republic of Irelandlocal authorityis responsible for certain localPublic servicesservicessuch assanitation,planningandReal estate developmentdevelopment,librarylibraries, the collection ofautomobilemotortaxation, localroadsandsocial housing.

The county is part of theDublin (European Parliament constituency)Dublinconstituency for the purposes ofElections in the European UnionEuropean elections. For elections toDil ireann, the area of the county is today divided into twelve constituencies:Dublin Central (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin Central,Dublin MidWest (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin MidWest,Dublin North (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin North,Dublin NorthCentral (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin NorthCentral,Dublin NorthEast (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin NorthEast,Dublin NorthWest (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin NorthWest,Dublin South (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin South,Dublin SouthCentral (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin SouthCentral,Dublin SouthEast (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin SouthEast,Dublin SouthWest (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin SouthWest,Dublin West (Dil ireann constituency)Dublin WestandDn Laoghaire (Dil ireann constituency)Dn Laoghaire. Together they return 47 deputies (Teachta DlaTDs) to the Dil.
article.heading: Dublin Region
article.paragraph: File:Ireland location map Dublin region.svgthumbalt=The Dublin region ofRepublic of IrelandIrelandwith each constituent county/city council highlighted.TheDublin Regionis aNomenclature of Territorial Units for StatisticsNUTSLevel IIIList of regions of the Republic of IrelandregionofRepublic of IrelandIreland. The region is one of eight regions of the Republic of Ireland for the purposes ofEurostatstatistics. Its NUTS code is IE021. It is co-extensive with the old county. The regional capital isDublinDublin Citywhich is also the national capital.
article.heading: Dissolution of Dublin County Council

link.part: View of Killiney Bay fromKilliney Hill

article.paragraph: Dublin County Council (which did not include thecounty boroughof Dublin) was abolished in 1994 and the area divided among the administrative counties ofDn LaoghaireRathdown,FingalandSouth Dublineach with itscounty towncounty seat. To these areas may be added the area of Dublin city which collectively comprise the Dublin Regioncite webhttp://www.irishstatutebook.ie/ZZSI394Y1993.htmlLocal Government Act, 1991 (Regional Authorities) (Establishment) Order, 199331 July 2009(langgaRéigiúin Átha Cliath) and come under the remit of the Dublin Regional Authority.

The area lost its administrativecountystatus in 1994, with Section 9 Part 1(a) of theLocal Government (Dublin) Act, 1993stating that "the county shall cease to exist."Act of the Oireachtas:Local Government (Dublin) Act, 1993 (Section 9 Part 1(a))Local Government (Dublin) Act, 1993 Section 2specifies:the county, in relation to any time before the establishment day, means the administrative county of Dublin.In discussing the legislation to dissolve Dublin County Council,Avril DoyleTeachta DlaTDsaid, "The Bill before us today effectively abolishes County Dublin, and as one born and bred in these parts of Ireland I find it rather strange that we in this House are abolishing County Dublin. I am not sure whether Dubliners realise that that is what we are about today, but in effect that is the case."Dil ireann:Parliamentary Debates (3 November 1993)

Despite the legal status of the Dublin Region, the term "County Dublin" is still in common usage. Many organisations and sporting teams continue to organise on a "County Dublin" or "Dublin Region" basis. The area formerly known as "County Dublin" is now defined in legislation solely as the "Dublin Region" under theLocal Government Act, 1991 (Regional Authorities) (Establishment) Order, 1993,and this is the terminology officially used by the four Dublin administrative councils in press releases concerning the former county area. The termGreater Dublin Area, which might consist of some or all of the Dublin Region along with counties ofCounty KildareKildare,County MeathMeathandCounty WicklowWicklow, has no legal standing.

The latestOrdnance Survey Ireland"Discovery Series" (Third Edition 2005) 1:50,000 map of the Dublin Region, Sheet 50, shows the boundaries of the city and three surrounding counties of the region. Extremities of the Dublin Region, in the north and south of the region, appear in other sheets of the series, 43 and 56 respectively.

link.part: Three RockMountain, Dublin, Ireland looking towards Bray Head

list.listitem: Local radio stations includeDublin's 98FM98FM,FM104,Dublin City FM103.2 Dublin City FM,Dublin's Q102Q102,SPIN 1038,Sunshine 106.8,TXFM,Raidi Na LifeandRadio Nova 100FM (Ireland)Radio Nova.
Local newspapers includeThe Echo (Irish newspaper)The Echo,Northside People,Southside Peopleand theLiffey Champion.

article.paragraph: Most of the area can receive the five main UK television channels on analogue television as well as the main Irish channels, along with Sky TV andVirgin Media Irelandcable television.
article.heading: Transport

list.listitem: Road:The major roads are theN2 road (Ireland)N2,N3 road (Ireland)N3,N4 road (Ireland)N4andN7 road (Ireland)N7national primary roads, and theM1 motorway (Republic of Ireland)M1,N11 road (Ireland)M11andM50 motorway (Ireland)M50motorways.
Heavy rail:TheInterCity (Iarnrd ireann)InterCityandCommuter (Iarnrd ireann)Commuterrail services (Iarnrd ireann).
Light rail:TheLuastram system servingDublinDublin Cityand its southern and western suburbs.
Rapid transit:TheDublin Area Rapid TransitDARTand the proposedDublin Metroline.

article.heading: Economy
article.paragraph: The economy of County Dublin was identified as being the powerhouse behind theCeltic Tiger, a period of strong economic growth of the state. This resulted in the economy of the county expanding by almost 100% between the early 1990s and 2007. This growth resulted from incoming high-value industries, such as financial services andsoftware manufacturing, as well as low-skilled retail and domestic services, which caused a shift away from older manufacturing-industry.This change saw high unemployment in the 1980s and early 1990s which resulted in damage to the capitals social structure.

http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/submitViewTableAction.doAccording to Eurostat figures for 2012, the region has GDP of 72.384 bn and a GDP per capita of 57,200 the highest on the island of Ireland (the second highest is Cork with 48,500)
article.heading: Transport
article.paragraph: See alsoTransport in DublinCounty Dublin is the main transport node of Ireland,and contains one international airport,Dublin Airport. It is also served by two main seaports, Dn Laoghaire port andDublin Port, which is just located outside of the city center. The two main train stations areDublin HeustonandDublin Connolly, both of which serve intercity trains.
article.heading: Demographics
article.paragraph: According to the 2006 census, County Dublin had a population of 1,187,176, which constitutes 30% of the national population. This was an increase of 9.5% on 2002 figures. Its population density was 1,218/km. The population of Dublin City, was 506,211.

The median age of the population of the county in the 2006 census was 35.6 years, with 62% of people aged between 2064 years old. Net migration to the county between 2002 and 2006 was 48,000, with a natural increase of 33,000 people.

There are 10,469 Irish speakers in County Dublin attending the 31Gaelscoils(Irish language primary schools) and eightGaelcholiste(Irish language secondary schools).cite webhttp://www.gaelscoileanna.ie/assets/Staitistic%C3%AD-2010-2011_Gaeilge.pdfOideachas Trí Mheán na Gaeilge in Éirinn sa Ghalltacht 2010-20112011gaelscoileanna.ieIrish9 January 2012There may be up to another 10,000 Irish speakers from the Gaeltacht living and working in Dublin also.
